23 1.0 INTRODUCTION Langan Engineering, Environmental, Surveying, Landscape Architecture and Geology, D.P.C. (Langan) prepared th is Interim Remedial Meas ures Work Plan (IRMWP) on behalf of Gowanus President Owner LLC (the Volunteer) for the property at 514 Union Street, Brooklyn, New York (the site) . The Volunteer was accepted into the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation (NYSDEC) Brownfield Cleanup Program (BCP) to investigate and remediate the site pursuant to the NYSDEC Brownfield Cleanup Agreement (BCA) executed on 21 October 2021 . The site was assigned BCP Site No. C224318 . This IRMWP proposes contain ment and stabiliz ation of a chlorinated volatile organic compound (CVOC) groundwater plume by prevent ing the migration of the plume and reduc ing CVOC concentrations, to the extent feasible . Plume containmen t and stabilization , and dissolved CVOC concentration reduction will be achieved by in -situ application of remediation products designed to capture and enhance biodegradation of CVOCs. The IRMWP was prepared in accordance with the process and requirements of the BCP and the May 2010 Division of Environmental Remediation (DER) Technical Guidance for Site Investi gation and Remediation (DER -10). 1.1 Site Description The approximately 17,000 -square -foot site, identified as Brooklyn Borough Tax Block 440, Lot 12, is located in an urban area in the Gowanus neighborhood of Brooklyn, New York, and consists of an one-story brick building occupied by the Royal Palms Shuffleboard Club. A site location map is included as Figure 1 . The site is located on the block bound by Union Street to the north, 3rd Street to the east, President Street to the south, and Nevins Street to the west. The south -adjoining parcel, 473 President Street, is in the NYSDEC BCP (BCP Site No. C224220). The east - and west -adjoining parcels, identified as President Street Portfolio, are also in the NYSDEC BCP (BCP Site No. C224309). The Gowanus Canal (a National Priorities List [NPL] site) is located about 350 feet west of the site. Prior to occupancy by the Shuffleboard Club, the site opera ted as a manufa cturing and storage warehouse. In 2013 , the warehouse was retrofitted with an elevated wooden platform to support a new finished floor over the majority of the footprint . The building improvements include shuffleboard courts, an office, ba rs, restrooms, storage areas, and a one -car pa rking garage. An about 2 - to 23 -inch-thick void space exists between the finished floor platform and the concrete building foundation slab. A site plan is included as Figure 2 . The July 2022 NYSDEC -approved IRMWP was implemented in September 2022 to install a soil vapor intrusion (SVI) mitigation system. The system has been operating since 22 September Interim Remedial Measures Work Plan No. 2 514 Union Street Brooklyn, New York Langan Project No. 170361307 2 February 2023 Page 2 of 23 2022. Implementation of the July 2022 IRMWP will be documented in a forthcoming Construction Completion Report (CCR). A remedial investigation (RI) was conducted between 31 August and 12 September in accordance with the NYSDEC -approved 28 July 2022 Remedial Investigation Work Plan (RIWP). RI results will be documented in a forthcoming Remedial Investigation Report (RIR). 1.2 Proposed Development As of the date o f this IRMWP, t here are no proposed development plans. The site will continue to operate as a shuffle board club for the foreseeable future. 1.3 Physical Conditions 1.3.1 Site and Regional Topography According to the 23 July 2021 Architectural Survey by New York City Land Surveyors, PC , the Union Street sidewalk elevations (el) fronting the site range from about el 141 to el 11, sloping down from east to west . The topography of the surrounding area is generally flat, but gradually slopes down from east t o west towards the Gowanus Canal . 1.3.2 Site and Regional Geology According to the RI conducted by Langan from 31 August to 12 September 2022 , the site is underlain by fill generally characterized as dark gray to brown fine sand with varying amounts of gravel, silt, cobbles , concrete , coal fragments , coal ash, slag, glass and organic fibers . Fill was observed below the concrete slab to depths ranging between 2 and 14 feet below grade surface (bgs). Fine-grain ed sand with varying amounts of silt and gra vel was observed below the fill layer to the boring termination depths (10 to 27 feet bgs). United States Geological Survey (USGS) "Bedrock and Engineering Geologic Maps of New York County and Parts of Kings and Queens Counties, New York, and Parts of Be rgen and Hudson Counties, New Jersey" indicate that bedrock underlying the site is part of the Hartland Formation. The Hartland Formation is comprised of mica schist and quartz -feldspar granulite, with localized intrusions of granite and pegmatite. A geo technical investigation report, dated October 2021 and prepared by Pillori Associates, P.A. (Pillori) for the 473 President and President Street Portfolio sites , documents 18 exploratory geotechnical borings completed between December 2019 and September 20 21. According to the geotechnical boring logs, the stratigraphy generally consists of fill underlain by brown sand with trace amounts of silt and gravel. Cobbles and boulders were encountered between 40 and 90 feet bgs. The borings were advanced to a ma ximum depth of about 102 feet bgs. Bedrock was not encountered in any exploratory borings. 1 Elevations herein are in feet and referenced to the North American Vertical Datum of 1988 (NAVD88). Interim Remedial Measures Work Plan No. 2 514 Union Street Brooklyn, New York Langan Project No. 170361307 2 February 2023 Page 3 of 23 1.3.3 Site and Regional Hydrogeolog y Groundwater flow is typically topographically influenced, as shallow groundwater tends to originate in areas of topographic highs and flows toward areas of topographic lows, such as rivers, stream valleys, ponds, and wetlands. A broader, interconnected hydrogeological network often governs groundwater flow at depth or in the bedrock aquifer. Groundwater depth and flow directi on are also subject to hydrogeological and anthropogenic variables such as precipitation, evaporation, extent of vegetation cover, and coverage by impervious surfaces. Other factors influencing groundwater include depth to bedrock, the presence of histori c fill material, and variability in local geology and groundwater sources or sinks. Site groundwater ranged from approximately el 2.29 to el 2.74 (corresponding to approximately 9.5 and 10.5 feet bgs) during the September 2022 RI . Groundwater elevations r anged from about el 2.1 to el 3.1 during remedial investigations performed at 473 President Street (BCP Site No. 224220) and President Street Portfolio (BCP Site No. C224309) between March 2017 and November 2019. Groundwater flow direction is west toward the Gowanus Canal. Groundwater elevation contour s are shown on Figure 3. 1.4 Site History Prior to the current occupant, the site was used by various manufacturing and industrial facilities since as early as 1886. Current and historic al site uses include the following: The Royal Palms Shuffleboard Club (2013 - present) Manufacturing and Storage (1993 - 2007) Dolin Metal Manufacturing Co. (1969 - 1992) Coca -Cola Bottling Co. of NY (1938 - 1950) Albro J. Newton Co. Trim and Planing Mill (1904 - 1915) Kenyon and Newton Sash and Door Factory (1886) 1.5 Previous Environmental Reports 24 July 2014 Phase I Environmental Site Assessment, prepared by Carlin, Simpson & Associates Phase I Environmental Site Assessment (ESA), dated July 24, 2014, prepared by Carlin, Simpson & Associates (CSA) The Phase I ESA was prepared for a larger area, including the site. Findings of the Phase I ESA as they relate to the site are as follows: Interim Remedial Measures Work Plan No. 2 514 Union Street Brooklyn, New York Langan Project No. 170361307 2 February 2023 Page 4 of 23 The property has a history of industrial uses including Dolin Metal Manufacturing Co., Coca -Cola Bottling Co. of NY, and Albro J. Newton Co. Trim and Planing Mill, with limited information regarding waste management and housekeeping practices, which may ha ve contributed to contamination at the site. Contaminated groundwater from nearby off -site sources, including the Gowanus Canal (a National Priorities List [NPL] site) and 318 Nevins Street (petroleum -contaminated groundwater attributed to on -site petrole um bulk storage), may have impacted groundwater at the site. 473 President Street, an adjacent property to the south currently enrolled in the NYSDEC BCP (BCP Site No. C224220), is associated with open NYSDEC Spill No. 9412605 for a petroleum release duri ng a tank test failure that may have impacted groundwater at the site. 30 April 2021 Limited Subsurface Investigation Report, prepared by Langan The limited subsurface investigation was implemented between 19 and 21 March 2021 to assess the potential for soil vapor intrusion into the existing site building and investigation environmental subsurface conditions at the site . The investigation included collection of soil, groundwater, sub-slab vapor, indoor air and ambient air samples. Laboratory analytical results indicative of CVOC impacts to soil and groundwater include: CVOC Impacts to Soil: One CVOC, trichloroethene (TCE), was detected in two soil samples from a soil boring in the southeastern part of the site. TCE was detected in the sample collected from 1 to 3 feet bg s at 12 milligrams per kilogram (mg/kg) ( above the Unrestricted Cleanup Objective [SCO2] of 0.47 mg/kg) , and in a sample collected from 7 to 9 feet bgs at 140 mg/kg ( above the Restricted Use Restricted Residential [RURR ] SCO of 21 mg/kg) . CVOC Impacts to Groundwater: At least one CVOC was detected at concentrations above the corresponding NYSDEC Standards and Guidance Value s (SGV3) in all five groundwater samples collected during the March 2021 limited subsurface investigation . The highest CVOC concentrations were detected in the sample collected from monitoring well MW02 in the southwestern part of the site. TCE was detected at concentrations above the NYSDEC SGVs in 3 of 4 monitoring wells, ranging from 14 micrograms per liter ( µg/L) at 2 SCOs promulgated in the NYSDEC Title 6 of the Official Compilation of New York Codes, Rules, and Regulations (NYCRR) Part 375. 3 NYSDEC SGVs promulgated in the NYSDEC 6 NYCRR Part 703.5 and the NYSDEC Technical and Operational Guidance Series (TOGS) 1.1.1 Ambient Water Quality Standards and Guidance Values for Class GA Water . Interim Remedial Measures Work Plan No. 2 514 Union Street Brooklyn, New York Langan Project No. 170361307 2 February 2023 Page 5 of 23 monitoring well MW03, located southern part of the site , to 140 µg/L at monitoring well MW02 , located in the southwestern part of the site . Preliminary Remedial Investigation Data , prepared by Langan The remedial investig ation was implemented between 31 August and 12 September 2022 to investigate and characterize the nature and extent of the contamination at and/or emanating from the site; and inform the in -situ remedial alternative. The investigation includ ed collection of soil and groundwater samples. Findings and conclusions as they relate to CVOC contamination in soil and groundwater are as follows : 1. Stratigraphy : A fill layer was encountered from below the building slab to depths ranging from about 2 feet bgs in the so utheastern portion of the site to about 8 to 13 feet bgs throughout the rest of the site. The fill generally consists of dark gray to brown fine sand with varying amounts of gravel, silt, red cobbles, concrete, coal fragments, coal ash, slag, glass and organic fibers . The fill layer is underlain mainly by brown to tan , fine sand with varying amounts of silt and gravel. In some borings , the fill was underlain by a 2.5 - to 5-foot-thick brown to tan silt layer. Bedrock was not encountered in any of the soil borings. 2. Hydrogeology : Groundwater was encountered from about el 2.29 to el 2.74 in shallow monitoring wells (screened from 5 to 17 feet bgs) , corresponding to approximately 9.5 and 10.5 feet, respectively, below grade . The inferred gr oundwater flow direction is to the west toward the Gowanus Canal. 3. CVOC -Impacts : TCE was detected in four shallow soil samples (0 to 2 feet bgs) above the UU SCOs. The following s ix CVOCs were detected in at concentrations above NYSDEC SGVs in of cis -1,2-DCE in groundwater samples collected from monitoring wells MW09D and MW11D were detected at 3,000 µg/L and 2,800 µg/L; and concentrations of TCE were detected at 8,300 µg/L and 6,900 µg/L, respectively - about three orders of magn itude above the NYSDEC SGVs. The presence of CVOCs in soil and groundwater is Interim Remedial Measures Work Plan No. 2 514 Union Street Brooklyn, New York Langan Project No. 170361307 2 February 2023 Page 6 of 23 attributed to historical releases associated with the former uses of the site and 473 President Street for metals manufacturing, a planing mill, and/or bottling. 1.6 Soil Cont aminant Conditions Three VOCs - acetone, total xylenes, and TCE - were detected in soil samples at concentrations above UU SCOs collected during the September 2022 RI. Soil sample analytical results from the September 2022 RI and May 2021 Limited Subsurfa ce Investigation are shown on Figure 4 . Concentrations of one CVOC (TCE) was detected above the UU SCO in shallow soil samples (0-2 feet bgs) TCE was detected concentrations above the UU SCO ranging from 3.7 mg/kg in SB16_0 -2, located in the south -central part of the site, to 120 mg/kg in SB15_0 -2, located in the southeastern part of the site. TCE in soil was delineated vertically and horizontally by deeper samples and surrounding borings. TCE was not detected at concentrations above the UU SCO below 2 feet bgs in soil samples collected during the September 2022 RI . TCE was detected at concentrations above the UU SCO in unsaturated soil sample s collected during the March 2021 limited subsurf ace investigation from 1 to 3 feet bgs and from 7 to 9 feet bgs from the southeast ern part of the site. Non-aqueous phase liquid (NAPL) was not identified during previous investigations. The unsaturated TCE soil impacts are not a continuous source of grou ndwater impacts given the lack of NAPL and the presence of an impervious site cover which prevents water infiltration through the unsaturated soil. The unsaturated TCE soil impacts are a source of soil vapor contamination and soil vapor intrusion (SVI) is being mitigated by the operation of a SVI mitigation system. 1.7 Groundwater Contaminant Conditions CVOCs and petroleum -related VOCs were detected in groundwater samples above the NYSDEC SGVs collected during the September 2022 RI. Groundwater sample analytical results from the September 2022 RI are shown on Figure 5 . Groundwater TCE concentrations for all groundwater samples collected to date at the site and the two adjoining BCP sites (473 President Street/BCP Site No. C224220 and President Street P ortfolio/BCP Site No. C224309) are shown on Figure detected at concentrations above NYSDEC SGVs in nine groundwater samples . CVOC concentrations in groundwater were high er in wells scre ened at "intermediate" intervals (between 15 and 27 feet bgs), and were highest in monitoring wells MW09D and MW11D, located along the southern and western perimeters of the site , respectively . Concentrations of cis -1,2-DCE in the groundwa ter samples collected from monitoring wells MW09D and MW11D were 3 ,000 µg/L and 2,8 00 µg/L, respectively ; and concentrations of TCE were 8,300 µg/L and 6, 900 µg/L, respectively - more than three orders of magnitude above the NYSDEC SGVs. CVOC concentrations were detected Interim Remedial Measures Work Plan No. 2 514 Union Street Brooklyn, New York Langan Project No. 170361307 2 February 2023 Page 7 of 23 above the NYSDEC SGVs at monitoring wells screened as deep as 27 feet bgs; however, CVOCs were not detected above the NYSDEC SGVs in monitoring wells screened below 27 feet bgs . Interim Remedial Measures Work Plan No. 2 514 Union Street Brooklyn, New York Langan Project No. 170361307 2 February 2023 Page 8 of 23 2.0 SUMMARY OF INTERIM R EMEDIAL MEASURES This IRM WP includes the following tasks to support in-situ groundwater remediation : 1. Development and implementation of a site-specific Construction Health and Safety Plan (CHASP) for the protection of on -site workers , tenants, and the communit y during remedia tion; 2. Collection of baseline groundwater samples from existing monitoring wells MW07 D, MW08 D, MW11D ,MW13D and HRP -MW-1 (off -site well installed by others) , and new monitoring wells MW14S and MW15D ; 3. Application of PlumeStop ® Liquid Activated Carbon (PlumeStop ®), Microemulsion (3DME ®)4 via injections at varying targeted doses designed to capture and enhance biode gradation of CVOCs . The remedial products will be mixed together and diluted with water on -site and applied in batches with varying dosages. The in -situ groundwater remedy will contain and stabilize the CVOC groundwater plume by prevent ing the migration of the plume and reduc ing CVOC concentrations, to the extent feasible ; 4. To demonstrate effectiveness, c ollecti on of post-remediation groundwater samples from existing MW11D ,MW13D and HRP -MW-1 (off -site by others) and new wells MW14S and MW15D ; and 5. Preparation of a Construction Completion Report (CCR) to document implementation of this IRMWP . These tasks are further des cribed in the ensuing sections. 2.1 Objectives and Rationale Based on the results of previous subsurface investigations and the RI, the following Remedial Action Objectives (RAO) have been Regenesis ® of San Clemente, California. Interim Remedial Measures Work Plan No. 2 514 Union Street Brooklyn, New York Langan Project No. 170361307 2 February 2023 Page 9 of 23 RAOs RAOs for Public Health Protection RAOs for Environmental Protection Groundwater Preve nt ingestion of groundwater with contaminant levels exceeding drinking water standards. Prevent contact with, or inhalation of volatiles, from contaminated groundwater Restore ground water aquifer to pre-disposal/pre -release conditions, to the extent practicable. Plume containment/stabilization to prevent, to the extent feasible, the down -gradient migration of the groundwater plume Developed in accordance with DER -10 4.1(d)2.ii and 4.1(d)2.iii , t his IRMWP proposes containment and stabilization of a CVOC groundwater plume and reduction of CVOC concentrations , to the extent feasible. The objective s of this IRMWP include the following: 1. Containment and stabil ization of a CVOC groundwater plume by prevent ing the migration of the plume through a permeable reactive barrier ; and 2. Reduction of dissolved CVOC concentrations in groundwater through sorption to liquid activated carbon followed by anaerobic biodegra dation via in -situ chemical reduction . CVOCs -related VOCs were detected in groundwater above NYSDEC SGVs in multiple samples . A permeable reactive barrier, four ®), will be implemented along the perimeter of the site via injection points. The in-situ groundwater treatment plan is detailed in Section 2.4. Following IRM implementation , the planned construction and remediation at the adjoining development site will preclude access to the proposed in -situ groundwater treatment area. The planned remediation for the development site involves the installation of an air sparge/soil vapor extraction (AS/SVE) system , set forth in the 7 July 2022 Remedial and Miti gation System Design Technical Memorandum prepared by Langan . Following the temporary one-time injection points, residual CVOC -impacted groundwater will continue treatment through the AS/SVE system, once installed. The AS/SVE system will continue operati on until remediation objectives for the development site are achieved. Remedial components for the site (injection points and SVI mitigation system) and the adjoining BCP sites (AS/SVE system and vapor collection system) are shown on Figure 7. The timing of the proposed IRM as it relates to the development site remediation is further discussed in Section 3.0. All activities that will result in soil disturbance will be completed in accordance with requirements of the site-specific Construction Health and Safety Plan (CHASP) and the Community Air Monitoring Plan (CAMP) contained therein in a manner to prevent exposure of potential impacts to site workers and the surrounding community. Interim Remedial Measures Work Plan No. 2 514 Union Street Brooklyn, New York Langan Project No. 170361307 2 February 2023 Page 10 of 23 2.2 Remedial Design Investigation Methodology Analytical data was collected to evaluate in -situ remediation alternatives during the September 2022 RI . The investigation and sampling method ologies and analytical results as they pertain to remedial design criteria are described in the following sections . Remedial Design Investigation Methodology Seven soil borings , SB05 SB08, and SB14 through SB16, were completed by AARCO Environmental Services Corp. (AARCO) between September 6 and 12, 2022 . Borings were advanced using a limited access Geoprobe ® 420M direct -push drill ing rig and a hand -held hammer drill with a 2.5 -inch coring drill bit was used to pre -clear the concrete slab at each boring location. Localized removal of the finished wooden floor platform was completed to expose the unde rlying concrete slab and provide access to each boring location. The two borings sampled for remedial design criteria depths are summarized as follows: Boring SB08 was advanced to 27 feet bgs Boring SB07 was advanced to 21 feet bgs due to refusal Continuo us soil samples were collected from the surface to the final depth of each boring. Samples were collected from the Geoprobe ® 420M into 4-foot-long acetate liners . The soil was screened for visual, olfactory, and instrumental evidence of environmental imp acts, and was visually classified for soil type, grain size, texture, and moisture content. Instrument screening for the presence of VOCs was performed with a photoionization detector ( PID) equipped with a 10.6-electron volt (eV) lamp . Following sample collection, the borings were converted to groundwater monitoring wells. Excess soil was containerized in United Nations/Department of Transportation (UN/DOT )-approved 55 -gallon steel drums with sealed lids in preparation for off -site disposal. Four soil borings (SB05, SB06, SB07, and SB08) monitoring wells (MW05D, MW06D, MW07D, and MW08D, respectively). The two monitoring wells selected to evaluate remedial design parameters, MW07D and MW08D, were constructed b y advancing 5 or 10 feet of 1 -inch diameter 0.01 -inch slotted schedule 40 PVC well screen with attached riser into the boreholes. MW07D was screened from 15 to 20 feet bgs using 5 feet of 1 -inch diameter 0.01 -inch slotted schedule 40 polyvinyl chloride ( PVC) well screen due to refusal at 21 feet bgs, and about one foot of borehole cave -in. MW08D was screened from 17 to 27 feet bgs using 10 feet of 1 -inch diameter 0.01 -inch slotted schedule 40 PVC well screen and attached riser to the surface. Following installation, each well was developed using a submersible whale pump. Development water was placed into labeled drums and stored on -site pending off -site disposal. Interim Remedial Measures Work Plan No. 2 514 Union Street Brooklyn, New York Langan Project No. 170361307 2 February 2023 Page 11 of 23 Remedial Design Sampling Samples submitted for VOC analysis were collected directly from the acetate liner via laboratory -supplied Terra Core ® soil samplers. For all other analyses, t he sample volume was homogenized and placed in appropriate laboratory -supplied sample containers . The sample containers were labeled, placed in a laboratory -supplied cooler and packed on ice (to maintain a temperature of 4±2°C). Samples were relinquished to a courier for delivery to Alpha Analytical Laboratories (Alpha), a New York State Department of Health ( NYSDOH ) Environmental Laboratory Approval Program (EL AP)-certified laboratory in Westborough, Massachusetts , under standard chain -of-custody protocol. Two grab soil samples in total were collected from soil boring SB07 and SB08 for remedial design analysis . Both soil samples were analyzed for grain size, total solids (TS), iron, manganese, nitrate, nitrite, ammonia, phosphate, sulfate, alkalinity, biological oxygen demand (BOD), chemical oxygen demand (COD), total organic carbon (TOC) . Monitoring wells were sampled in genera l accordance with the EPA's low -flow groundwater sampling procedure to allow for collection of a representative sample ("Low Stress [low flow] Purging and Sampling Procedure for the Collection of Groundwater Samples from Monitoring Wells", EQASOP -GW 001, J anuary 19, 2010). Prior to sample collection, groundwater was purged from each well until either groundwater parameters (pH, conductivity, turbidity, dissolved oxygen [DO], temperature, and oxidation -reduction potential [ORP]) had stabilized and turbidity measurements were below 50 Neph elometric Turbidity Units (NTU) or one hour had lapsed. Two groundwater samples, collected from monitoring wells MW07D and MW08D were analyzed for TCL VOCs by EPA to support the evaluation of an in -situ remedial alternative. In addition to collecting groundwater samples to inform remedial design, a Langan field engineer installed a FluxTracer ® Flux Mapping Tool in monito ring well MW11D, wh ere had chemical -like impacts (i.e., visual, olfactory, and/or PID readings above background) were most apparent. The device was installed on 12 September 2022 and removed on 26 September 2022 and was sent to Regenesis ® of San Clemente, California for analysis. The FluxTracer ® consists of five separate two -foot-long stainless steel canisters, each filled with granular activated carbon pre -loaded with biodegradable tracers. The FluxTracer ® determined groundwater speed and contaminant ma ss upon analysis. The FluxTracer ® data was used in the select ion and design of the groundwater remedy, and is incl uded as Appendix A . 2.3 Remedial Design Investigation Results Following the two -week deployment period, the FluxTracer ® was analyzed for Darcy velocity, representing the volume of water that flows through the porous canisters per one -foot interval Interim Remedial Measures Work Plan No. 2 514 Union Street Brooklyn, New York Langan Project No. 170361307 2 February 2023 Page 12 of 23 measured in centimeters per day (cm/day), and contaminant flux, representing the mass of contaminants that adsorb to the FluxTracer ® canisters per one -foot interval measured in milligrams per cubic meter per day (mg/ m3/day) . To determine Darcy velocity , the FluxTracer ® device reveals the amount of alcohol tracers that have desorbed from the granular activated carbon from groundwater passing through the steel canisters over the two -week deployment period. As the plume travels with groundwater flow, contaminants adsorb to the activated carbon within the steel canisters. The contaminants are extracted during analysis to determine contaminant mass flu x and concentration. The Darcy velocity and contaminant flux are used to determine contaminant mass at one -foot intervals. The contaminant fluxes for TCE, PCE, and cis -1,2-DCE are divided by the Darcy velocity at each one -foot interval to show flux -derived concentrations for each of the three contaminants. The FluxTracer ® data at monitoring well MW11D shows that the highest concentrations of TCE and cis -1, 2-DCE are at about 18 feet bgs at about 1,180 µg/L and 150 µg/L, respectively. The flux-derived c oncentration for PCE at all intervals were non -applicable because the Darcy velocity and/or PCE detection was less than the reporting limit. PCE was detected at concentrations about one order of magnitude less than the cis -1,2-DCE concentration, and about two orders of magnitude less than TCE concentration. Concentrations of TCE and cis -1,2-DCE steadily decrease with depth after the peak at about 18 feet bgs. The FluxTracer ® analytical results provide Darcy velocity, contaminant flux, and contaminant con centrations from about 13 feet bgs to about 22 feet bgs. In combination with groundwater sample analytical results, the FluxTracer ® data was used to define the target treatment zone (TTZ) and remedial product dosages. Additional analyses were performed on soil and groundwater samples collected from the southeastern and southwestern parts of the site to model subsurface conditions in detail and determine remedial product dosages. Two grab soil samples were collected from soil borings SB07 and SB08 and analyzed for grain size, TS, iron, manganese, nitrate, nitrite, ammonia, phosphate, sulfate, alkalinity, BOD, COD, and TOC. Two groundwater samples were collected from monitoring wells MW07D and MW08D and analyzed for TCL VOCs by EPA 8260C MW07D_090922 to 1.55E+01 cells/mL in MW08D_090922. The groundwater design criteria sample results for DHC at the site did not i ndicate dechlorinating bacteria activity above the target threshold of 104 cells/mL ; however, the presence of PCE/TCE breakdown products cis -1,2-DCE and vinyl chloride suggests that some br eakdown has occurred. Interim Remedial Measures Work Plan No. 2 514 Union Street Brooklyn, New York Langan Project No. 170361307 2 February 2023 Page 13 of 23 Tables 1 and 2 pr esent the results of the remedia l design parameter analyses . 2.4 In-Situ Groundwater Treatment 2.4.1 Technical Description of In -Situ Groundwater Treatment The CVOC plume will be contained and stabilized via temporary one-time injections of PlumeStop ®, a matrix of activated carbon suspended in water ; S-MicroZVI ®, a fast-release containing DHC bacteria, and other microbes and enzymes to p erform anaerobic biodegradation; and 3DME ®, a multi -staged -release donor product to enhance an aerobic biodegradation. The remedial products will be mixed together and diluted with water on -site and applied in batches with varying dosages . As a result of sorption and biodegrada tion, dissolved CVOC concentrations in groundwater will also be reduced. After the PlumeStop ® application, fine particles of activated carbon will coat soil surfaces , where dissolved phase CVOCs will then sorb into the PlumeStop ®. Following CVOC sorption, colonizing bacteria and microbes in the form of BDI PLUS ® breakdown the CVOCs to non -toxic end products via reductive dechlorination. The process is stimulated by the fast -release electron donor S-MicroZVI ®, which creates a reducing environment. The fast - and slow -release electron donor 3DME ® will be applied , along with BDI PLUS ® and S-MicroZVI ®, to accessible up -gradient areas. The multi -stage release of electron donors in 3DME ® allows the product to flow through the subsurface matrix with gro undwater to otherwise inaccessible areas to complete the permeable reactive barrier . Due to the adjacent building to the west , northwestern perimeter injection points are not feasible. The application of the 3DME ® dose inside the one -car parking garage, located in the northwestern part of the site, is intended to stimulate anaerobic biodegradation once the products adjoin the down -gradient permeable reactive barrier along the western part of the site. Limited access inside the occupied site bu ilding precludes on -site injection points at the suspected source area in the southeastern part of the site. The application of the 3DME ® -dose along the eastern perimeter of the site is intended to allow the products to reach the suspected on -site CVOC sour ce area through groundwater flow , located in the south to southeastern parts of the site before stimulating anaerobic biodegradation. About 19,600 pounds of PlumeStop ®, 1,200 3DME ®, 3,200 pounds of S -MicroZVI ®, and 54 liters of BDI PLUS ® will be applied , totaling 40,008 gallons of remedial products , to construct the permeable reactive barrier. Collectively, these combinations of remedial products create a permeable reactive barrier to reduce CVOC concentrations, and contain and stabilize the CVO C plume beneath the site in order to prevent, to the extent practicable, the migration of Regenesis ®, of San Clemente, California; technical specification s and safety data sheets (SDS) for these Interim Remedial Measures Work Plan No. 2 514 Union Street Brooklyn, New York Langan Project No. 170361307 2 February 2023 Page 14 of 23 products are included in Appendix B. Proposed locations are s hown on Figure 8. 2.4.2 Application Methodology The remedial injection products are grouped into three application and water will be combined in mix vessels and applied in batches at 12 injection points along the southern and western perimeters. Each injection point will contain about 924 gallons of PLUS ® will be combined in mix vessels and applied in batches at 28 injection points along the southeastern and south to southwestern perimeters. Each injection point will contain about 895 gallons of PlumeStop ®, S-MicroZVI ®, and BDI BDI PLUS ®, will be combined in mix vessels and applied in batches at 12 injection points along the eastern and northwestern perimeters of the site. Each injection point will contain about 320 gallons of 3DME ®, S-MicroZVI ®, and BDI PLUS ® mixture . reactive barrier will be applied directly to CVOC -impacted and up -gradient areas via about 52 temporary injection points across the southern, eastern, and western perimeters of the site. A summary of the three appl ication strategies are tabulated as Number of Injection Points 12 28 12 Remedial Product Mixture Volumes Per Injection Point PlumeStop® : 85 gallons S-MicroZVI® : 5.5 gallons BDI PLUS® : 1.5 liters Water: 83 3 gallons PlumeStop® : 41 gallons S-MicroZVI® : 5 gallons BDI PLUS® : 0.5 liters Water: 849 gallons 3DME® : 12 gallons S-MicroZVI® : 5.5 gallons BDI PLUS® : 1.5 liters Water: 288 gallons Total Mixture Volume per Injection Point 924 gallons 895 gallons 306 gallons Target Treatment Zone (feet bgs) 10 to 30 10 to 30 10 to 30 Application of the permeable reactive barrier will be conducted via a direct -push drill rig. The remedial application will target the 10 to 30 feet bgs interval . Direct push injection point locations (IP01 through I P52) are shown on Figure 8. Interim Remedial Measures Work Plan No. 2 514 Union Street Brooklyn, New York Langan Project No. 170361307 2 February 2023 Page 15 of 23 The anticipated radius of influence for the permeable reactive barrier injections via direct -push is 4 feet. The proposed injection points are about 6 feet apart in their respective application strategy areas. Injections will be made using a "bottom -up" approach, beginning at the deepest injection zone and raised in 2 -foot or 3-foot intervals to the top of the gro undwater table. The TTZ is defined from the top of the groundwater table (about 10 feet bgs) to 30 feet bgs. Injection points will be completed through a retractable steel rod equipped with either a 2 -foot- or 3-foot-long slotted section. At each injection point, the steel rod will be advanced to 30 feet bgs . The total volume and concentration within the TTZ at each injection point will be determined by the injection point's high -dose, low- dose , or 3DME ® dose classification. Dosage concentrations are further discussed in the design document prepared by Regenesis ® included in Appendix B. Figure 8 shows the proposed groundwater treatment area. The Regenesis ® groundwater treatment design is detailed in Appendix B. 2.5 Groundwater Monitoring Baseline Sampling One baseline groundwater sample will be collected from existing groundwater monitoring wells and new monitoring wells MW14S and MW15D . These groundwater samples are intended to establish baseline results for future performance monitoring. Monitoring wells selected for baseline sampling are subject to change a ccording to field conditions. Prior to sampling , the monitoring wells will be purged. Purging will consist of pumping, at a minimum, the stabilized drawdown volume plus the pump's tubing volume, and waiting until the physical and chemical parameters (e.g., temperature, dissolved oxygen, oxygen reduction potential, tu rbidity) stabilize within the ranges specified in the USEPA's Low Stress Purging and Sampling Procedure for the Collection of Groundwater Samples From Monitoring Wells, dated July 30, 1996, and 4 th revision September 19, 2017. Samples will be collected wi th a submersible pump and dedicated polyethylene tubing. The pump will be decontaminated with Alconox ® and water between each sample location. Development and purge water will be containerized for off -site disposal. The groundwater samples will be coll ected in laboratory -supplied containers and will be sealed, labeled, and placed in an ice -chilled cooler (to maintain a temperature of about 4ºC) for delivery Interim Remedial Measures Work Plan No. 2 514 Union Street Brooklyn, New York Langan Project No. 170361307 2 February 2023 Page 16 of 23 to the laboratory. Groundwater samples will be analyzed for CVOC5 compounds detected above the NYSDEC SGVs during the September 2022 RI using the latest USEPA methods for VOCs . QA/QC procedures to be followed are des cribed in the QAPP in Appendix C. Post-Remediation Sampling Post-injection groundwater sample s will be collected existing groundwater monitoring wells MW07D, MW08D MW11D, MW13D, and HRP -MW-1 (off -site and new wells MW14S and MW15D . Well MW11D is located on the adjoining development site and may get destroyed during implementation of the remedy for the adjoining development site. MW11D will be replaced by the installation of development site wells RD-MW02S and RD -MW02D . Once instal led wells RD -MW02S and RD -MW02D will be sampled in lieu of MW11D. The first sampling event will take place about 30 days after the injection s are completed . Post-injection groundwater samples will be collected on a quarterly basis for the first year following the injection program . After one year, the sampling frequency will be reassessed based on analytical results. The samples will be submitted to an NYSDOH ELAP -certified laboratory for analysis of CVOCs. The Construction Completion Report will i nclude results of at least the first two quarterly sampling events . Although well HRP -MW-1 will be monitored following the injections , CVOC concretions in HRP-MW-1 are expected to be directly impacted by the proposed injection program give the distance fro m the site. The numbers of wells to be monitored may be reduced based on a review of the results and with the NYSDEC's written concurrence. The decision to discontinue groundwater sampling will be made in consultation with NYSDEC and will consider wh ether remaining contaminant concentrations have: Decreased to levels below applicable NYSDEC standards, as practicable; or Become asymptotic over an extended period of time as mandated by the NYSDEC and the NYSDOH. The groundwater monitoring locations may be subject to change based on construction/remediation at the adjoining development site. Any additional groundwater monitoring requirements will be address ed in the forthcoming RAWP . 5 Groundwater samples will be analyzed for TCE, PCE, ci s-1,2-dichloroethene, vinyl chloride, 1,1-dichloroethene, and trans -1,2-dichloroethene. Interim Remedial Measures Work Plan No. 2 514 Union Street Brooklyn, New York Langan Project No. 170361307 2 February 2023 Page 17 of 23 Purged Groundwater and Decontamination Fluids Management Excess remediation phase -derived waste including purged groundwater, and decontamination fluids, will be containerized in properly -labeled and sealed UN/DOT -approved 55 -gallon drums and staged for future waste characterization and off -site disposal at a facility permitted to accept the waste. T he drums will be staged in an area on -site, pending receipt of laboratory data and off -site disposal to an appropriate facility. T he site will be secured during and after investigation to prevent public access to the site. 2.6 Remediation Oversight The Remedial Engineer ( RE), Jason Hayes, P.E., of Langan, will oversee implementation of th is IRMWP. The RE is responsible for documenting that the contractor performs the work as specified in this IRM WP and for providing required documentation to the NYSDEC as part of the CCR described below in Section 4. 2. A Langan representative , under the supe rvision of the RE, will provide oversight d uring implementation of th is IRMWP . Work conducted in accordance with this IRM WP will be documented in daily field reports, monthly BCP progress reports, and in the CCR. 2.7 Odor, Vapor, and Nuisance Control Plan Community air monitoring will be conducted during ground -intrusive work (i.e., advancement of injection points) in compliance with the NYSDOH Generic CAMP outlined be low and included in Appendix D. CAMP will consist of continuous monitoring for VOCs and dust emissions during ground -intrusive activities. Ground intrusive activities includ e, but are not limited to the installation of injection points. Special Require ments, as included in Appendix D, will be adhered to for indoor work or occupied structures within 20 feet . Upwind concentrations will be measured at the start of each workday to establish background concentrations. VOCs and dust emissions will be monitore d at the downwind perimeter of the work zone, which will be established at a point on the site where the general public or site employees may be present. Periodic monitoring for VOCs is required during non -intrusive activities such as the collection of groundwater samples from existing monitoring wells. "Periodic" monitoring during sample collection might reasonably consist of collecting a reading upon arrival at a sample location, monitoring while opening a well cap or overturning soil, monitoring durin g well bailing/purging, and collecting a reading before leaving a sample location. CAMP monitoring for VOC levels will be conducted with a PID , and monitoring for dust/particulates will be conducted with a particu late sensor equipped with a filter to detec t particulates less than 10 microns in diameter (PM10). Monitoring for particulates and odors will be conducted during all ground intrusive activities by the RE's field inspector. The work zone is Interim Remedial Measures Work Plan No. 2 514 Union Street Brooklyn, New York Langan Project No. 170361307 2 February 2023 Page 18 of 23 defined as the general area in which machinery is operati ng in support of remediation activities. A portable PID will be used to monitor the work zone and for periodic monitoring of VOCs during activities such as groundwater sampling. The site perimeter will be visually monitored for fugitive dust emissions. The following actions will be taken based on VOC levels measured: If total VOC levels exceed 5 ppm above background for the 15 -minute average at the perimeter, work activities will be temporarily halted and monitoring continued. If levels readily decrease (per instantaneous readings) below 5 ppm above background, work activities will resume with continued monitoring. If total VOC levels at the downwind perimeter of the work zone persist at levels in excess of 5 ppm above background but less than 25 ppm, wo rk activities will be halted, the source of vapors identified, corrective actions taken to abate emissions and monitoring continued. After these steps work activities will resume provided that the total organic vapor level 200 feet downwind of the work zo ne or half the distance to the nearest potential receptor or residential/commercial structure, whichever is less - but in no case less than 20 feet, is below 5 ppm above background for the 15 -minute average. If the total VOC level is above 25 ppm at the p erimeter of the work zone, activities will be shut down. The following actions will be taken based on visual dust observations: If the downwind particulate level is 100 µg/m³ greater than background (upwind conditions measured at the start of each workday ) for the 15 -minute period or if airborne dust is observed leaving the work zone, then dust suppression must be employed. Work may continue with dust suppression techniques provided that downwind PM10 levels do not exceed 150 µg/m³ above the background lev el and provided that no visible dust is migrating from the work zone. If, after implementation of dust suppression techniques, downwind PM10 levels are greater than 150 µg/m³ above the background level conditions measured at the start of each workday , work must be stopped and a re -evaluation of activities initiated. Work can resume provided that dust suppression measures and other controls are successful in reducing the downwind PM10 concentration to within 150 µg/m³ of the upwind level and in preventing v isible dust migration. Due to VOC impacts present at the site, s pecial requirements for work within 20 feet of potentially exposed i ndividuals or structures have been established. If work areas are within 20 feet of potentially exposed populations or occu pied structures, the continuous monitoring locations for VOCs and particulates must reflect the nearest potentially exposed individuals and Interim Remedial Measures Work Plan No. 2 514 Union Street Brooklyn, New York Langan Project No. 170361307 2 February 2023 Page 19 of 23 the location of ventilation system intakes for nearby structures. The on -site building is not expected to be occupi ed during injection point installation. The use of engineering controls will be considered to prevent exposures related to the work activities and to control dust and odors. If total VOC concentrations opposite the walls of occupied structures or next to intake vents exceed 1 ppm, monitoring should occur within the occupied structure(s). Background readings in the occupied spaces must be taken prior to commencement of the planned work. Any unusual background readings should be discussed with NYSDOH prior to commencement of the work. If total particulate concentrations opposite the walls of occupied structures or next to intake vents exceed 150 µg/m3, work activities should be suspended until controls are implemented and are successful in reducing the tot al particulate concentration to 150 µg/m3 or less at the monitoring point. Concentrations above actions levels observed in the CAMP will be reported to the NYSDEC and NYSDOH Project Managers and included in the daily report. In addition, a map showing t he location of the downwind and upwind CAMP stations will be included in the daily report. 2.8 Construction Health and Safety Plan The RE oversaw preparation of a CHASP for the site, and the adjoining parcels , which is provided as Appendix E. The CHASP provides a mechanism for establishing on -site safe working conditions, safety organization, procedures, and personal protective equipment requirements. The CHASP meets the requirements of 29 CFR 1910 and 29 CFR 1926 (which includes 29 CFR 1910.120 an d 29 CFR 1926.65, respectively). The CHASP includes, but is not limited to, the following components listed below: Organization and identification of key personnel Training requirements Medical surveillance requirements List of site hazards Excavation saf ety Work zone descriptions and monitoring procedures Personal safety equipment and protective clothing requirements Decontamination requirements Standard operating procedures Contingency plan Safety data sheets Interim Remedial Measures Work Plan No. 2 514 Union Street Brooklyn, New York Langan Project No. 170361307 2 February 2023 Page 20 of 23 2.9 Quality Assurance Project Plan The RE oversaw the preparation of a QAPP, which includes proposed sampling procedures and analytical methods for sample s to be collected during IRMWP implementation . The QAPP is provided in Appendix C. Remedial construction for the development site is anticipated to begin in March 2023, afte r the implementation of the IRM. The AS/SVE system installation is expected to be complete d by the third quarter of 2024 . The first post -injection sampling event will take place 30 days after the in-situ groundwater treatment program. Performance monitoring will continue on a quarterly basis for the first year following the in-situ groundwat er treatment . A CCR will be submitted to NYSDEC following two performance monitoring sampling events, as described in Section 4.2. 3.1 Notification The NYSDEC will be notified at least seven days prior to the start of field work . A pre -construction meeting will be coordinated between the RE, the contractor, and the NYSDEC. This meeting will take place prior to the implementation of this IRM WP. Interim Remedial Measures Work Plan No. 2 514 Union Street Brooklyn, New York Langan Project No. 170361307 2 February 2023 Page 22 of 23 4.0 REPORTING During the performance monitoring phase of the IRM WP implementation , a CCR will be prepared and submitted to the NYSDEC . The RE responsible for certifying the CCR will be an individual licensed to practice engineering in the State of New York. Jason J. Hayes , P.E. of Langan will have this responsibility. Should Mr. Hayes become unable to fulfill this responsibility, another suitably qualified New York State professional engineer will take his place. All project reports will be submitted to the NYSDEC electronically. If required, l aboratory analytical data will be submitte d in an electronic data deliverable (EDD) format that complies with the NYSDEC's electronic data warehouse standards. 4.1 Daily Reports Daily reports will be prepared for the project file and for review by the NYSDEC Project Manager. The daily reports will include: An update of progress made during the reporting day Locations of work and quantities of material imported to and exported from the Site References to a site plan A summary of any and all complaints with relevant details (names, phone numbers, etc.) A summary of CAMP findings, including exceedances An explanation of notable site conditions Daily reports are not intended to be the mode of communication for notifying the NYSDEC of emergencies (e.g., accidents, spills, etc.), requests for changes to this IRMWP , and/or other sensitive or time critical information; however, such conditions will also be included in the daily reports. Emergency conditions, changes, and/or any deviations to this IRMWP will be addressed directly to the NYSDEC Project Ma nager via telephone or email. If site conditions warrant, the RE may request to change from daily to weekly reports that include the above information. 4.2 Construction Completion Report A CCR will be submitted to the NYSDEC Project Manager after two post-injection performance monitoring sampling events . The CCR will document the implementation of the remedial action undertaken as an interim remedial measure . The CCR will be incorporated into and referenced in the FER for the site when issued. REGENESIS received 1 set of 10' passive flux meter device from Langan Engineering and performed FluxTracer analysis to determine Darcy flux, mass flux, and flux derived contaminant concentration. The quantitative FluxTracer test measur es the amount of alcohol tracers that desorbed from the activated carbon due to ground water passively flowing through the cylinder cannister s. Under these test conditions, the Darcy velocity and contaminant flux for the groundwater plume can be interpreted as Indicator Yellow Low <2 - 5 <96 - 240 <10 - 300 Yellow to Orange Medium 5 - 15 240 - 719 300 - 800 Orange to Red High 15- >30 719 - 1437 800 - >2000 *Seepage rate assumes a 0.25 porosity Flux derived concentration is derived using the following equation: (/)= (/2/) (/)10 A non -applicable (N/A) is applied to the intervals where either the Darcy velocity, contaminant of concern, or both is less than the reporting limit. A value of ND <X indicates that the analyte of concern is NOT detected above the method detection limit (MDL) or the method reporting limit (MRL) . A J-value indicates that the analyte of concern was detected and that the analyte concentration is an estimated value which is between the method detection limit (MDL) and the method reporting limit (MRL). Description of Experimental Methods A batch reactor is filled with 10 grams of sample from each 1 -foot interval and is extracted for alcohol tracers followed by extraction of chlorinated volatile organic solvents (CVOCs) using of isobutanol and acetone -hexane , respectively. Batch reactors are then placed on a sh aker for 24 hours. A 1 ml extract from each batch reactor is transferred to a liquid gas chromatography vial and each sample is analyzed by a GC -FID for alcohol tracers and GC-MS for CVOCs. Quantitatio n procedures of Darcy and mass flux can be found in , https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/es050074g . PlumeStop High Dose to access pr oduct specification sheetsProject Goals Technologies Proposed Technical Resources PlumeStop® Technical Bulletin 2.1: Sorption of Contaminants from 14, 2022Figure 1-Injection L ocation Mapregenesis.com |3Technical Approach We are proposing the application of PlumeStop® Liquid Activated Carbon (PlumeStop) and Sulfidated-Micro Zero Valent Iron (S-MicroZVI®) to treat residual chlorinated solvents. Together, these technologies will foster rapid concentration reductions and provide long-term treatment of the target compounds through sorption plus abiotic destructive pathways, while minimizing the potential for daughter product formation. PlumeStop is a colloidal form of activated carbon with a surface treatment which reduces its interactions with the soil matrix. This allows it to move through soil pores leaving a coating on the soil matrix as it distributes from the injection point. This provides a very large sorption surface which will result in immediate reduction of these contaminants while concentrating contaminants to allow for more efficient and controlled remediation through destructive technologies. S-MicroZVI is a concentrated suspension of sulfidated, colloidal zero-valent iron, designed for enhanced, long-lasting reactivity and ease of application relative to other forms of ZVI. When applied to the subsurface it imparts an in-situ chemical reduction (ISCR) mechanism that allows for the direct destruction of chlorinated ethenes (i.e. TCE) via abiotic degradation pathways, which minimizes the formation of daughter products such as vinyl chloride. Sulfidation of the ZVI surface significantly decreases the reaction that occurs between water and the ZVI particles, allowing the reagent tobemore effective forthechemical reduction ofchlorinated ethenes. This approach combines enhanced reductiv e ) and abiotic in-situ ents. The its longe vity (se veral y ears) allow for sufficient co verage with minimal pore volume displacement thereb y minimizing application costs. Our colloidal zero-valent iron (ZVI) product, Sulfidated- MicroZVI (S-MicroZVI®), will pro vide a source of iron, creating conditions for abiotic reduction via the formation of iron sulfides, o xides, and h ydro xides, while also maintaining strongly reducing conditions in the treatment area for an extended timefr ame. This will foster r apid abiotic reduction of chlorinated solv ents while reducing the potential for daughter product formation compared to a standard in-situ bioremediation approach. Bio-Dechlor INOCULUM®Plus (BDI Plus) is added to pro vide a liv e microbial culture that is known to fully degr ade these compounds. Table 2: Remedial Design P arameters Summary PlumeStop High Dose 3DMEregenesis.com |5Design V erification T esting (D VT) Design V erification T esting (D VT) is a term used to describe a suite of field sampling/testing activities carried out before implementing a subsurface substr ate injection progr am. The purpose is to v erify that the subsurface conditions at the selected application location match those conditions used in the design. P erforming the D VT step pro vides critical data input to the design team allowing to adjust the necessary elements in the design. These design adjustments significantly impro ve substr ate placement and result in an o verall impro vement in remedial performance and reduction in o verall project cost. DVT will be conducted during the remediation mobilization and will consist of pre-injection soil cores. Additionally , REGENESIS is recommending installing a FluxT racer in a well near the planned barrier . FluxT racer is a de vice that is deplo yed into the satur ated screened interval of a monitoring well, that can accur ately determine groundwater speed and chlorinated solv ent mass flux, both are instrumental in the successful design of PlumeStop barriers. A FluxT racer unit consists of a series of 2-foot pre-strung canisters, that can be installed into 2-inch monitoring well for appro ximately two weeks. Each canister contains activated carbon and biodegr adable tr acers. As groundwater natur ally moves through the FluxT racer , contaminants are sorbed to the activated carbon, and the tr acers are depleted from activated carbon. The amount of sorbed contaminants is used to determine mass flux, while the depletion of the tr acers can estimate groundwater speed. Initial construction and lab analysis is completed b y REGENESIS, lea ving only the installation and retrie val to the client. Placement Validation (PV) Placement V alidation (PV) seeks to e valuate that the designed injection point spacing and v olumes are adequate to achie ve proper distribution within the target treatment zone. Evaluation will be based on the reagent fluid monitoring at nearb y monitoring locations during the injection process and modifications ma y be made to the design if initial field tests are not satisfactory . PV is also used to document visual product sorption onto aquifer materials after its initial colloidal fluid state. As such, RRS will conduct various field tests to e valuate the distribution and influence of the remedial reagents in the subsurface throughout the injection application. These site--specific PV field tests will typically be conducted in strategically-located quality control segments within the injection area footprint. These segments are commonly referred to as as "clusters" . The field tests ma y include pre-injection soil cores to view the lithology and confirm v ertical treatment as designed; installation of tempor ary piezometers to monitor water le vel, groundwater par ameters, and groundwater color; and lastly , collection of post-injection soil cores to observ e reagents adhered to the aquifer matrix where desired. In gener al,RRS ma y utilize se veral field test procedures in combination or individually to e valuate the distribution and influence of the remedial reagents being applied. Responsibilities for each are outlined in this section and further under the Assumptions/Qualification section. At the beginning of each da y a safety tailgate meeting will be conducted and an o verview of the procedures, responsibilities and goals for the da y will be discussed. RRS will be equipped with multiple injection tool options to use with 1.5-inch diameter DPT rods. The injection tool string will be advanced to the top or bottom of the TTZ and injections will be performed in a bottom-up or top-down method depending on site and lithology conditions. The remediation technologies will be mix ed in an injection tr ailer (Figure 2) with water in batches at the designated solution percentage and k ept in constant suspension throughout the injection application. Pressures, flow r ates and total v olume will be monitored and digitally documented for each injection interval. Multiple injection points ma y be injected into simultaneously to increase efficiencies on-site. The injection points and surrounding areas will be monitored for an y signs of surfacing and a spill response kit will be on standb y.RRS Scope of Services During the application, real-time information will be collected and analyzed to help v erify design assumptions and subsurface reagent distribution. Depending on the primary product applied, data collected and analyzed ma y consist of groundwater quality par ameters (i.e., pH, conductivity , DO , ORP , etc.), depth to water measurements, visual indicators through groundwater or soil samples, and in-field injection concentr ation test kits. This information is typically collected during the application when within 10 feet of an appropriately screened monitoring well. Based on the information collected, the project team ma y choose to modify the remediation design to further optimize the injection application. This includes modification to injection concentr ations, v olume per v ertical foot, injection intervals, etc. Once the injection e vent is completed, RRS will demobilize all equipment and personnel off-site. PlumeStop is composed of very ne particles of activated carbon (1-2µm) suspended in water through the use of unique organic polymer dispersion chemistry. Once in the subsurface, the material behaves as a colloidal biomatrix, binding to the aquifer matrix, rapidly removing contaminants from groundwater, and expediting permanent contaminant biodegradation. This unique remediation technology accomplishes treatment with the use of highly dispersible, fast-acting, sorption-based technology, capturing and concentrating dissolved-phase contaminants within its matrix-like structure. Once contaminants are sorbed onto the regenerative matrix, biodegradation processes achieve complete remediation at an accelerated rate. It is engineered to provide an optimal source of micro-scale zero valent iron (ZVI) that is both easy to use and delivers enhanced reactivity with the target contaminants via multiple pathways. S-MicroZVI can destroy many chlorinated contaminants through a direct chemical reaction (see Figure 1 ). S-MicroZVI will also stimulate anaerobic biological degradation by rapidly creating a reducing environment that is favorable for reductive dechlorination. Sulfidated ZVI S-MicroZVI is composed of colloidal, sulfidated zero-valent iron particles suspended in glycerol using proprietary environmentally acceptable dispersants. The passivation technique of sulfidation, completed using proprietary processing methods, provides unparalleled reactivity with chlorinated hydrocarbons like PCE and TCE and increases its stability and longevity by minimizing undesirable side reactions. T o see a list of treatable contaminants, view the S-MicroZVI treatable contaminants guide.Figure 1: Chlorinated ethene degradation pathways and products. The top pathway with single line arrows represent the reductive dechlorination (hydrogenolysis) pathway. The lower pathway with downward facing double line arrows represent the beta- elimination pathway.S-MicroZVI T echnical DescriptionS-MicroZVI Specification Sheet S-MicroZVI is Best in Class For Longevity Reactivity Transport S-Micro In addition to superior reactivity, S-MicroZVI is designed for easy handling that is unmatched by any ZVI product on the market. Shipped as a liquid suspension, S-MicroZVI requires no powder feeders, no thickening with guar, and pneumatic or hydraulic fracturing is not mandatory. The information in thesheet was written based on the best knowledge and experience currently available.Disclaimer S-MicroZVI or S-MZVI SDS US (3DME® ) is comprised of a patented molecular structure containing oleic acids (i.e., oil component) and lactates/polylactates, which are molecularly bound to one another (gure 1). The 3DME molecule contains both a soluble (hydrophilic) and insoluble (lipophilic) region. These two regions of themolecule are designed to be balanced in size and relative strength. The balancedhydrophilic/lipophilic regions of 3DME result in an electron donor with physical properties allowing it to initially adsorb to the aquifer material in the area of application, then slowly redistribute via very small 3DME "bundles" calledmicelles. These 3DME micelles spontaneously form within sections of theaquifer where concentrations of 3DME reach several hundred parts per million. The micelles' small size and mobility allow it to move with groundwater flow through the aquifer matrix, passing easily through the pore throats in betweensoil grains resulting in the further redistribution of 3DME within the aquifer. This allows for advective distribution of the oleic acids which are otherwise insoluble and unable to distribute in this manner, allowing for increased persistence of thelactate/polylactates component due to their initial attachment to the oleic acids. Due to its patented molecular structure, 3DME oers far greater transport when compared to blended emulsied vegetable oil (EVO) products, which fail to distribute beyond the limits of pumping. 3DME also provides greater persistence when compared to soluble substrates such as lactates or simplesugars. The 3DME molecular structures capitalize on the best features of the two electron-donor types while at the same time, minimize their limitations. 3DME is delivered to the site as a ready-to-apply emulsion that is simply dilutedwith water to generate a large volume of a 3DME colloidal suspension. Suspension of 3DME generated by this mixing range from micelles on the order of .02 microns to .05 microns in diameter, to "swollen" micelles, (termed "microemulsions") which are on the order of .05 to 5 microns in diameter. Once injected into the subsurface in high volumes, the colloidal suspension mixes and dilutes in existing pore waters. The micelles/microemulsions on the injection front will then begin to sorb onto the surfaces of soils as a result of zeta potential attraction and organic matter within the soils themselves. As the sorption continues, the 3DME will "coat" pore surfaces developing a layer of molecules and in some cases a bilayer. This sorption process continues as the micelles/microemulsion moves outward and disassociates into their hydrophilic/hydrophobic components. The specialized chemistry of 3DME results in a staged release of electron donors: free lactate (immediate); polylactate esters (mid-range) and free fatty acids & fatty acid esters (long-term). Material longevity of three years or greater has been seen at most sites as determined from biogeochemical analyses. Operating Procedure Quality Assurance Project Plan 514 Union Street, Brooklyn, New York Langan Project No. 170361305 NYSDEC BCP Site No. C224318November 2022 Page 1 of 27 1.0 PROJECT DESCRIPTION 1.1 Introduction Langan Engineering, Environmental, Surveying, Landscape Architecture and Geology, D.P.C. (Langan) prepared this Quality Assurance Project Plan (QAPP) on behalf of 473 President LLC (the Volunteer) for the property at 514 Union Street, Brooklyn, New York (the site). The Volunteer was accepted into the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation (NYSDEC) Brownfield Cleanup Program (BCP) to investigate and remediate the site pursuant to the NYSDEC Brownfield Cleanup Agreement (BCA) executed on 21 October 2021. The site was assigned BCP Site No. C224318. The approximately 17,000-square-foot site, identified as Brooklyn Borough Tax Block 440, Lot 12, is located in an urban area in the Gowanus neighborhood of Brooklyn, New York, and consists of an one-story brick building occupied by the Royal Palms Shuffleboard Club. This Quality Assurance Project Plan (QAPP) specifies analytical methods and evaluation procedures to be used to ensure that data from the proposed interim remedial measure (IRM) at the site are precise, accurate, representative, comparable, and complete. 1.2 Project Objectives IRMWP No. 2 proposes containment and stabilization of a chlorinated volatile organic compound (CVOC) groundwater plume to prevent the migration of the plume and reduce CVOC concentrations, to the extent feasible. Plume containment and stabilization will be achieved by in-situ application of remediation products designed to capture and enhance biodegradation of CVOCs. The IRMWP includes the following tasks to support groundwater treatment: Development and implementation of a site-specific Construction Health and Safety Plan (CHASP) for the protection of on-site workers, tenants, and the community during remediation; Collection of baseline groundwater samples from existing monitoring wells MW07D, MW08D, and MW13D; Application of PlumeStop® Liquid Activated Carbon and 3-D Microemulsion (3DME®)1 via injections at varying targeted doses designed to capture and enhance biodegradation of CVOCs. The i of San Clemente, California.Quality Assurance Project Plan 514 Union Street, Brooklyn, New York Langan Project No. 170361305 NYSDEC BCP Site No. C224318November 2022 Page 2 of 27 n-situ groundwater remedy will contain and stabilize the CVOC groundwater plume to prevent the migration of the plume and reduce CVOC concentrations, to the extent feasible; Collection of post-remediation groundwater samples from existing wells MW07D, MW08D, and MW13D to demonstrate effectiveness; and Preparation of a Construction Completion Report (CCR) to document implementation of the IRMWP. 1.3 Scope of Work The scope of work is described in detail in the IRMWP No. 2. Groundwater samples will be collected for laboratory analysis. An odor and organic vapor control and monitoring plan will be implemented during implementation of the IRMWP No. 2. Quality Assurance Project Plan 514 Union Street, Brooklyn, New York Langan Project No. 170361305 NYSDEC BCP Site No. C224318November 2022 Page 3 of 27 2.0 DATA QUALITY OBJECTIVES AND PROCESSES Data Quality Objectives (DQOs) are qualitative and quantitative statements to help ensure that data of known and appropriate quality are obtained during the project. DQOs for sampling activities are determined by evaluating five factors: Data needs and uses: The types of data required and how the data will be used after it is obtained. Parameters of Interest: The types of chemical or physical parameters required for the intended use. Level of Concern: Levels of constituents, which may require remedial actions or further investigations. Required Analytical Level: The level of data quality, data precision, and QA/QC documentation required for chemical analysis. Required Detection Limits: The detection limits necessary based on the above information. The quality assurance and quality control objectives for all measurement data include: Precision - an expression of the reproducibility of measurements of the same parameter under a given set of conditions. Field sampling precision will be determined by analyzing coded duplicate samples and analytical precision will be determined by analyzing internal QC duplicates and matrix spike duplicates. Accuracy - a measure of the degree of agreement of a measured value with the true or expected value of the quantity of concern. Sampling accuracy will be determined through the assessment of the analytical results of equipment blanks and trip blanks (organic analysis of aqueous matrices only) for each sample set. Analytical accuracy will be assessed by examining the percent recoveries of surrogate compounds that are added to each sample (organic analyses only), internal standards, laboratory method blanks, instrument calibration, and the percent recoveries of matrix spike compounds added to selected samples and laboratory blanks. Representativeness - expresses the degree to which sample data accurately and precisely represent a characteristic of a population, parameter variations at a sampling point, or an environmental condition. Representativeness is dependent upon the adequate design of the sampling program and will be satisfied by ensuring that the scope of work is followed and that specified sampling and analysis techniques are used. Representativeness in the laboratory is ensured by compliance to nationally-recognized analytical methods, meeting sample holding times, and maintaining sample integrity while the samples are in the laboratory's possession. This is accomplished by following all Quality Assurance Project Plan 514 Union Street, Brooklyn, New York Langan Project No. 170361305 NYSDEC BCP Site No. C224318November 2022 Page 4 of 27 applicable methods, laboratory-issued standard operating procedures (SOPs), the laboratory's Quality Assurance Manual, and this QAPP. The laboratory is required to be properly certified and accredited. Completeness - the percentage of measurements made which are judged to be valid. Completeness will be assessed through data validation. The QC objective for completeness is generation of valid data for at least 90 percent of the analyses requested. Comparability - expresses the degree of confidence with which one data set can be compared to another. The comparability of all data collected for this project will be ensured using several procedures, including standard methods for sampling and analysis, instrument calibrations, using standard reporting units and reporting formats, and data validation. Sensitivity - the ability of the instrument or method to detect target analytes at the levels of interest. The project manager will select, with input from the laboratory and QA personnel, sampling and analytical procedures that achieve the required levels of detection. The above objectives are discussed in detail in Section 4.0.
